name: Ukraine
currentCrisisSummary:
Since Russia's 2022 invasion, Ukraine suffers a devastating conflict, inflicting immense human suffering. Millions are displaced, cities destroyed, and tens of thousands killed.

The war is an act of brutal **Russian imperialism**, but inseparable from decades of eastward **NATO expansion**. It is a catastrophic outcome of **inter-imperialist rivalry**, turning Ukraine into a **proxy battleground**. Massive **Western arms flows** sustain the war but also deepen Ukraine's **dependency**. This **disaster capitalism** framework shapes the ongoing conflict and planned reconstruction.

imperialRoot.legacy:
Ukraine's history is marked by its position between **competing empires**. Subjected to the **Russian Empire** (colonial **Russification**) and later the **USSR** (centralised control, purges, ***Holodomor*** famine), this history informs national identity and Russia's **neo-imperial** claims.

Following the USSR's collapse, the **US/NATO** engaged in triumphalist **eastward expansion**, treating Eastern Europe as a strategic frontier, breaking assurances, and encircling Russia. This expansion created the **structural conditions** for conflict.

historicalContext.title: Post-Soviet Neoliberalism and Oligarchy
historicalContext.description: The '**shock therapy**' economic policies promoted by the **IMF** in the 1990s were imposed on Russia and Ukraine. Rapid **mass privatisation** allowed politically connected **oligarchs** to accumulate wealth. This process **hollowed out the state**, created corruption, made economies **dependent** on exports, and vulnerable to **external pressures**. The conflict is partly a struggle between these rival **oligarchic capitalist states**.

historicalContext.title: NATO Eastward Expansion
historicalContext.description: The post-**Cold War expansion of NATO** was a primary driver of the crisis. Framed by the West as defensive, Russia perceived it as **aggressive encroachment**. This relentless **military expansion**, against warnings, created a **zero-sum security dilemma** shattering European peace and contributing to Russia's invasion decision.

historicalContext.title: The 2014 Maidan Uprising and Co-optation
historicalContext.description: The **Maidan Uprising** was a genuine, popular, and complex revolt against the corruption of the pro-Russian Yanukovych government. However, this popular energy was **co-opted by two forces**: pro-Western **neoliberal elites** seeking integration with the EU/IMF, and **ultranationalist far-right** groups (e.g., Right Sector, Svoboda) who provided militant street power. Russia responded by illegally annexing Crimea and instigating a war in the Donbas.

historicalContext.title: Internal Contradictions: Nationalism & Language
historicalContext.description: The post-2014 state-building project adopted a **hardline nationalist** position. This included the official rehabilitation of controversial WWII-era figures like **Stepan Bandera**, and the implementation of **language laws** that significantly restricted the use of Russian in public life and education. While aimed at de-Russification, these policies alienated large segments of the population in the east and south, providing a pretext for **Russian imperialist intervention**.

historicalContext.title: The Post-2014 Neoliberal Turn
historicalContext.description: Following Maidan, successive pro-Western governments, guided by the **IMF**, **World Bank**, and EU, implemented a second wave of deep **neoliberal reforms**. These included severe **austerity**, **privatisation**, and opening Ukraine's agricultural land market. Often conditions for **Western financial aid**, these policies deepened **economic dependency** and inequality.

historicalContext.title: War and Disaster Capitalism
historicalContext.description: The 2022 invasion created conditions for '**disaster capitalism**'. Western partners plan post-war reconstruction along **neoliberal lines**, funded by loans locking Ukraine into decades of **debt** to **international financial institutions**. This prioritises **privatisation** and opportunities for **foreign corporations**. The war serves as a **geopolitical battleground** and a mechanism for restructuring Ukraine's economy for **Western capital**.

historicalContext.title: International Law and Accountability
historicalContext.description: Russia's invasion violates the **UN Charter** and **international law**. **War crimes** are documented. The **ICC** issued warrants. Critics note the **selective application of international law** by Western powers (e.g., **Iraq, Libya**) lacking **accountability**, weakening the legal order.

humanitarianImpact.title: Casualties
humanitarianImpact.description: Tens of thousands of civilians killed by **Russia's aggression** and warfare. Military deaths number hundreds of thousands.

humanitarianImpact.title: Affected Population
humanitarianImpact.description: Est. 14.6 million require aid due to devastation from the **invasion** and subsequent **proxy war**.

humanitarianImpact.title: Displacement
humanitarianImpact.description: Approx. 3.7 million internally displaced by **Russian military advances, occupation, and attacks**.

humanitarianImpact.title: Refugee Crisis
humanitarianImpact.description: Over 6.5 million refugees globally, driven abroad by violence stemming from the **inter-imperialist conflict**.

humanitarianImpact.title: Ecocide: Kakhovka Dam
humanitarianImpact.description: The June 2023 destruction of the **Kakhovka Dam** unleashed catastrophic flooding, constituting **ecocide**. It wiped out ecosystems, contaminated the Black Sea, poisoned agricultural land with industrial pollutants, and crippled irrigation systems for Ukraine's 'breadbasket'.

humanitarianImpact.title: Healthcare Under Attack
humanitarianImpact.description: Over 1,500 attacks on healthcare, crippling access as **infrastructure is deliberately targeted**.

humanitarianImpact.title: Economic Devastation
humanitarianImpact.description: Economy shrunk by a third, plunging millions into poverty as war destroys infrastructure, exacerbated by **neoliberal vulnerabilities**.

timeline.event: **The Holodomor ('Death by Hunger')**: A man-made famine engineered by the Soviet state under Joseph Stalin kills millions of Ukrainians. The event is a foundational national trauma that informs Ukraine's deep-seated desire for sovereignty and its suspicion of Moscow's intentions.
**Independence**: Ukraine declares independence from the Soviet Union, marking a new era of sovereignty but also of geopolitical vulnerability between Russia and the West.

**Budapest Memorandum**: Ukraine agrees to give up its inherited Soviet nuclear arsenal in exchange for security assurances from Russia, the US, and the UK, guaranteeing its territorial integrityâ€”assurances later violated by Russia's invasions.
**First Wave of NATO Expansion**: Poland, Hungary and the Czech Republic join NATO, beginning the alliance's formal eastward push that Russia perceives as a threat.

**Orange Revolution**: Mass protests overturn a fraudulent presidential election, installing a pro-Western government. The event highlights the escalating tug-of-war over Ukraine's geopolitical alignment.

**Bucharest NATO Summit**: At its summit in Bucharest, NATO formally declares that Ukraine and Georgia 'will become members of NATO'. The declaration crosses a major Russian red line and is cited by many critical analysts as the point where a future conflict became highly probable.

**Maidan Uprising & Annexation of Crimea**: A popular uprising, which includes significant far-right elements, overthrows the elected pro-Russian government. Russia responds by illegally annexing Crimea and instigating a separatist war in the Donbas region.

**War in Donbas & Minsk II Failure**: An 8-year war between the Ukrainian state and Russian-backed separatists kills 14,000 people. The **Minsk II Agreements**, a diplomatic framework for autonomy, collapse due to unwillingness to implement them by all sides, entrenching the conflict.

**Full-Scale Russian Invasion**: Citing NATO expansion and the false pretext of 'de-Nazification', Russia launches a full-scale invasion of Ukraine, triggering the largest conventional war in Europe since WWII.
**War of Attrition & Proxy Conflict**: The war settles into a brutal conflict heavily supplied by NATO, confirming its status as a proxy war between Russia and the West fought on Ukrainian soil.

donate.description: A US-based non-profit that provides humanitarian aid to vulnerable populations and supports Ukraine in its efforts to build a strong civil society.
Provides critical humanitarian aid and works to build a prosperous, democratic and sovereign Ukraine.
A national society providing on-the-ground emergency aid, first aid, shelter, and psychosocial support to civilians affected by the conflict.
The official fundraising platform of Ukraine, initiated by President Volodymyr Zelenskyy, which directs funds to defence, medical aid and rebuilding.
A Ukrainian charitable foundation that provides psychological and psychosocial support to children affected by the war.

advocacy.title: Oppose All Imperialist Aggression
advocacy.description: Oppose all imperialist aggression, including Russia's invasion of Ukraine and the decades-long military expansion of NATO that created the conditions for war.

advocacy.title: Call for Ceasefire & Diplomacy
advocacy.description: Call for an immediate ceasefire and a negotiated diplomatic settlement to end the bloodshed, rather than military escalation.

advocacy.title: Cancel Ukraine's Foreign Debt
advocacy.description: Advocate for the cancellation of Ukraine's foreign debt to ensure that post-war reconstruction benefits its people, not international financial institutions and corporations.

advocacy.title: Support Peace Movements
advocacy.description: Support peace movements and conscientious objectors in Russia, Ukraine, and Belarus who oppose the war.

advocacy.title: Demand Self-Determination
advocacy.description: Demand self-determination for the Ukrainian people, free from domination by any foreign power, whether from the East or the West.

reading.title: *Frontline Ukraine: Crisis in the Borderlands*
reading.description: Richard Sakwa provides a critical analysis of the crisis's roots, focusing on Ukraine's internal divisions and the dual pressures from Russia and NATO.

reading.title: *The Tragedy of Great Power Politics*
reading.description: John Mearsheimer's foundational text on 'offensive realism,' framing the war as a predictable outcome of great power competition and NATO expansion.

reading.title: *Not One Inch: America, Russia, and the Making of Post-Cold War Stalemate*
reading.description: M.E. Sarotte's historical account reveals how US-led NATO expansion broke post-Cold War promises, setting the stage for conflict.
